We have reinstalled the wooden memorial cross at All Souls Church, and it is now back to its former glory. Our wood conservator removed the rotten wood from the cross, then carved and spliced new oak to fit and match the original woodwork. Photos courtesy of Richard Ellis. https://t.co/gZW95PLobE

https://t.co/yX6L9D6nn0 https://t.co/BufUCLaIBh

Learn more: https://t.co/fmx6ZxRCW7 https://t.co/Dypz6gYUHO

View, register and bid online:
https://t.co/BSIOpG0kSS https://t.co/nYgD0GRyz1

Auction:
https://t.co/sKFFONnFDV https://t.co/vFFxUorolI

Don't forget to register for our #Fine Clocks, Barometers & Scientific Instruments auction on 6 October.

A highlight from the #auction is Lot 204, this fine & rare #German #Renaissance gilt brass mounted ebonised crucifix #clock with alarm.

View auction:
https://t.co/yX6L9D6nn0 https://t.co/kYVfKYZSrY

Learn more: https://t.co/te19IHlI0j https://t.co/nT173qHnPJ

These are early Lovibond 'colorimeter' spectacles! Lovibond is best known as the inventor of the Tintometer, used for measuring light and colour, for  accurate testing in malting, brewing, dyeing, oil refining and water analysis. These are quite literally beer goggles!🍻

A headless skeleton was found along with the oak block beneath the floorboards of the Saracen's Head Inn in 1838. The old Debenhams building is said to be haunted by the ghost of the Duke.
3/3

On King Richard III's orders the Duke was executed for treason in the courtyard between the Blue Boar Inn and the Saracen's Head Inn. Both Inns are now demolished, but were situated within what is now the former Debenhams building.

The original hand is thought to be lost, but a replica is on display in a bread oven in the pub.
3/3

The hand is said to have been chopped from a ‘Demented Whist Player’ by a drunken butcher who suspected the player of cheating after numerous ‘lucky’ wins with pub regulars in the 1820s. The hand, along with these cards was discovered in 1903 during building works.
2/3

Two found shoes from Old Dairy Cottage were given to the museum in 1974, which leads us to wonder how the current inhabitants of the cottage are faring without their protective shoes! 
3/3

Beloved shoes, moulded to the shape of their owner's foot, were thought to embody the spirit of their wearer and would ward off evil spirits, ghosts and witches if kept concealed within the walls or floor of a building.
2/3

👹Spooky Week👹

Tis the season for spook, so this week we are sharing some of the weird and wonderful objects in our collection. 

Today’s object is an 18th Century shoe which was found hidden beneath the floorboards in the attic of Old Dairy Cottage on the Heale Estate.
1/3 https://t.co/i0xPdqLLgi
By the 19th Century funeral invitations had fallen out of fashion, being replaced with small memorial cards.

This particular example invites mourners to 'accompany the corps' of Mrs Elizabeth Graves to her final resting place. An image of a funeral procession ominously tells invitees to 'remember to die'. Artwork also features Death, holding an arrow, and Time, resting on an hourglass.

So two more after today... I would be doing a happy dance if I didn’t feel so crapy!!
